title: MLB DFS Single Games: NL Wild Card
text:
Welcome to the 2019 MLB Postseason! We’ll start things off with the NL Wild Card game between the Nationals and Brewers this evening. Washington RHP Max Scherzer and company are listed at -170 home favorites while facing Milwaukee RHP Brandon Woodruff in this winner-take-all contest.

We’ll highlight the top picks and best bargains to assemble a cash-inducing lineup. On top of that, the “additional notes” section will feature several tournament selections while adding context to the rest of this slate.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

Tuesday’s single-game slate begins at 8:05 ET.

TOP PLAYS

Juan Soto - OF - Washington

Soto tops the charts as potentially one of the best hitters of the night. He’ll have to fend off teammates Trea Turner and Anthony Rendon for that award, but keep in mind that Soto has a marginally cheaper salary as well. The Nationals are favored at home tonight while facing the lesser of either starting pitcher in Milwaukee’s Brandon Woodruff. If you are building cash lineups, Soto checks in as a strong contender for MVP consideration.

Trea Turner - SS - Washington

As mentioned in the previous write-up, Turner and Anthony Rendon (3B - WAS) can be argued as top overall picks as well. Turner can post fantasy upside from literally every category, but he admittedly holds less power than Rendon or Soto … As for Rendon, he’s expensive, but you won’t have to worry about him falling into lefty/lefty draws from the bullpen, unlike Soto.

NOTABLE BARGAINS

Story continues

Eric Thames - 1B - Milwaukee

Even though Nationals’ RHP Max Scherzer steps in as a sizable favorite, he’s not exactly bulletproof. The Washington ace has surrendered nine earned runs and four homers through 12.2 innings over his past two starts. There’s a chance “Mad Max” brings his best stuff in this win or go home scenario, but we have to identify the opening for Milwaukee’s power hitters. Thames is a boom-or-bust option who could pay dividends if Scherzer's homerun struggles carry into this tilt.

Matt Adams / Howie Kendrick - 1B - Washington

Whoever gets the start for Washington makes for an interesting bargain filler to help make the rest of your lineup work. There’s some concern with Adams struggling while dealing with a shoulder injury, but his rock-bottom salary accounts for that. It only takes one swing of the bat for him to deliver fantasy upside … As for Kendrick, he has been much better lately, racking up 16 hits over his past eight starts. I wouldn’t be surprised if he gets the start based on that hot-streak.

ALSO CONSIDER

Adam Eaton (OF - WAS) certainly deserve cash game looks while checking in as a cheaper pivot away from teammates Soto, Rendon, and Turner. While playing around with lineups, it seems like you can only fit two of those top three recommendations under the salary cap. That’s where Eaton comes in.

Let’s take a closer look at the Brewers, as there are some sneaky-good pivots against Scherzer’s deep-ball tendencies as of late. Mike Moustakas (3B - MIL) is an excellent tournament choice to jump on that, and he’s borderline cash playable as well. Yasmani Grandal (C - MIL) falls into the same rationale. He’ll probably carry a lower-than-deserved ownership rate, as it’s taboo to roster catchers at FLEX positions. However, Grandal has the necessary power to deliver, and the fact that he’s a switch-hitter doesn’t hurt.

Ryan Braun (OF - MIL) is 0-14 in his career against Scherzer. That will translate to an extremely low ownership rate in tournaments, meaning we have a leverage opportunity with the Milwaukee veteran. As mentioned earlier, it only takes one swing of the bat, and Braun could deliver in the late innings against Washington’s bullpen as well.
